@renzo_kookin4208 it's a science term. Mostly used in chemistry to define which liquids will easily mix (miscible). Non-polar molecules (i.e. oil, fat) tend to be hydrophobic. Polar molecules (i.e. water, alcohol) tend to be hydrophilic. Surfactants can alter surface tension between these two groups to make them miscible. 
Soap being used in water to remove fatty oils from the skin is an example of this.

replies.author: @ciganyweaverandherperiwink6293
replies.text:
Hear hear! What angers and astonishes me is that 'Woman' in 2022 is nothing but a 'concept'. We're an abstraction, an idea...something to work through in some over-processed, indulgent thought experiment. Just say you THINK you're one, and voila, you are. And you can change your mind at any time. Meanwhile the furniture that an entire society has rearranged to suit the latest whims of these people remains in situ with the rest of us remaining in the armchair that catches the afternoon glare and risks blinding us entirely. Are we expected to trot along behind these poorly integrated personalities, these fashion-focused emotionally incontinent nitwits, and cater to their ever changing temperaments and whims?! The hubris and self-obsessio! To call people either 'neurotypical' or 'neurodivergent' is a disgusting, arrogant, self-satisfied binary (how ironic, from the same group who hate 'binaries' and think everything is on a spectrum and always subjective). It's hideously decadent and solipsistic. Easy to ring fence yourself from criticism if you play the Identity Politics board game and can keep up with the changing rules.

The damage done by these spoilt, indulged humans toiling away in the fetid citadels of academia (and worse, absorbed by academic-activism) is far reaching, permanent and profound. A woman is not a 'concept'. I agree with your comment. How dare they. And worse, why have they been allowed to colonise every cultural, media and academic institution in the West and turn them into hives for the ideologically possessed? That this horse manure has been philosophically validated, socially enabled and allowed to gain very real political traction is the saddest indictment of the 'Silent Majority' I can think of. Not enough people stepped in to push back. We can't stop this mutation in our culture and society, but we can certainly hope that when the toxic dust settles, things don't seem so out of control and utterly insane. I hope some good clear thinking in our cultural architects starts as a murmur and then builds to something more quotidian where the 'every day citizen' doesn't have to worry about The Borg mind virus and feel empowered to speak more freely and honestly in general; a point where absurdities and radical propositions get the kibosh put on them and every day acceptance of the sensible ideas remain and the rest are stealthily put to pasture. Back into the verdant fields of academia, as thought experiments-- and not ones that we're all forced to LIVE through in our daily lives. I'd like the scaffolding to start falling apart with this crap.

Racist/Racism

Gender
Paedophilia
Trans
Transphobe
Woman
Misogyny
Insurrection
Riot
Peaceful Protest
Pregnancy
Breastfeeding
Equality

These are just off the top of my head and all from the last couple years. They're also now trying to redefine the term grooming because too many of them have been called out for grooming children. So once a word has been twisted and abused so it no longer holds any weight or meaning, can it really be considered still a word? That's the point I think he was making.


On a side note, I think a particular quote perfectly sums up wokeism and its pursuit of "rights" for groups/demographics that once had equal rights in the name of "necessity": "Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves." - William Pitt, 1783, in a speech made in the British House of Commons

replies.author: @tomaszwota1465
replies.text:
@ValosiTiamata I agree with _your_ point, but he didn't say it, now did he? He's a public speaker and yet uses some veiled implication, I don't know, a mental shortcut, instead of being clear about what he means to say. Why leave it up to interpretation so much?

I mean, you assume that's what he meant, and sure, it's a valid interpretation, but I disagree on the verbiage used just on the face value. Yes, it's still a word. An abused, mistreated, manipulated, loaded, but still very much a word. Heck, how do you even make a word not be a word? Erase it from everywhere it was used and make everyone forget it? I don't know.'

It definitely doesn't stop being a word when you don't like it or when it's used against you.

You can say I'm hung up on a technicality, but, man, I'm not in his head. He needs to be clear, not me. He needs to use the right words to express his ideas, not me.

replies.text:
Hate to be the one to say it, but it's primarily women that created and continue to enforce this disrespect and lack of safety. Just look at who supports this madness, it is and has always been almost exclusively women. Ultimately, most men have fought against these attacks on women and femininity, while most women have deliberately dismantled mens ability to protect them, and made men not see women as being worth protecting, by pushing for laws that disarm good men, take mens children from them, financially ruin them, and more.
I'm sure this will get some sort of "you're a misogynist!" response from someone, because some people would rather throw an insult than reflect, but it's factual. Women have stripped men of their ability to be protectors, and in recent years, begun stripping them of their desire to be protectors. My point is, ultimately, women have created a situation where the ones that would protect them are rendered powerless. This insanity continues because it's overwhelmingly women that support it, and women hold most of the power now. The only real way to make the world a place where femininity is respected and secured is for women to collectively say "we don't want this, this is insane, get it out of here," and either learn to make your own safety instead of saying you feel unsafe while expecting others to handle it, or collectively give people back the desire to keep you safe, and the protections that allowed them to do it.
Hold each other accountable. Hold yourselves accountable (whether it be for actively supporting it, or passively allowing it). Push back. Some women are pushing back now, but it's several years late, and still few and far between. Get involved in person. When there's any public event of this stuff, show up and heckle. When they try to "educate" (because YT doesn't like the word that rhymes with blooming) your children, take your kids out of that school and yell at the school board.
It's a problem that primarily women have created, and at this point, women have also made it so they're the only ones that can solve it. replies.author: @ValosiTiamata
replies.text:
I agree fully with this fact. I held down a highly abusive job for years due to child support, but in 2020, coworkers were becoming increasingly racist (including towards customers), so I spoke with child support, explained exactly what was going on, reminded them that I had a career to fall back on, and they not only agreed with my stance, they altered my order so I could quit.

I put in my notice with the understanding that it was a formality and I would not be coming back. A few days later, I got a call from the company's ethics department which spent 32 minutes accusing me of one racist thing after another. I told them what was going on in the store and they kept ignoring it. A few days after that, I got a call from my former boss who aid the company had issued a level 4 termination even though I didn't work for them (the termination was meant to make it harder for me to get work elsewhere even though I had quit). Two years later and the company's closed multiple stores and is practically rebranding itself to mimic a major competitor in an attempt to hold onto customers.

Meanwhile, I got to focus on my career and make around five times per hour what I did at that mess of a job. I'm able to be a stay-at-home dad and my work is flexible enough that I can take days off as I need to. And I don't have to answer to anyone but myself.


I know not everyone can start a self-employed career because it's really tough getting in the door (in my field, it took me nearly ten years to start raking in the big bucks and have a solid client base). But even if you can't, think about your skills and remember that most employers either value customer service above all else or are on a path of self-destruction. People are refusing to return to the workforce, so right now, you can have just about any job you want. If a company goes woke, move on so you'll be getting steady pay when they go broke and all your former coworkers end up on the dole.

Good people aren't as restricted as the wokeists want us to think. We actually hold all the real power and just have to remember this fact when their incessant bleating makes life tough.

replies.text:
Callum has been a very rocky cohost for me, but seems to be finally coming out if it the past week or so. As others have mentioned, he has that father/son dynamic with Carl which makes them a great combo, but there are only a couple cohosts he meshes well with. And I think that's perfectly okay, btu they should be pairing up hosts based on the chemistry, not just whomever seems to be available today.

The biggest problems I've had with Callum is that he'll sort of be off in his own little world. Granted, Leo is too abrasive for some cohosts (but bounces perfectly off of others such as John), so I'll exclude him as an example. But how many times has Callum been paired up with another host only to spend the entire episode examining his cuticles or staring off into space? This is mainly true when he's not the presenter, but can also happen when he's presenting an his cohost interrupts with an observation.

The past week or two, though, I've seen a welcome change in his attitude. He's actively engaged with his cohosts and seems to actually be enjoying himself. He's even cracking more jokes. I don't know if Carl had anything to do with it or Callum just had a lightbulb moment, but I really hope he keeps up this new momentum so one day he can be on par with John and Carl in terms of onscreen presence.

I'm also enjoying the spat of new guest hosts this week and thus far hope all of them come back.

replies.author: @TRENCHESandTREADS
replies.text:
@Paul2377  Except it isn't just your body, there's LITERALLY another human being inside it. God, why is this so hard for people to understand? If you don't want to suffer the consequences of having a kid, then don't have sex. You don't get to murder another human to absolve you of your own mistakes. Speaking of Orwellian, pro abortion people are clearly guilty of using Newspeak, even going so far as framing the entire debate in it. It's not Pro-Choice vs Pro-Life, in reality it's Anti-Consequences vs Pro-Life. The entire discussion around the topic has been warped because middle of the road dunces can't see that they've been propagandized to for decades. As far as I'm concerned, if you even remotely agree with anything that Sargon or others in his sphere have been talking about, then it's crazy to fall for such an obvious Newspeak lie like "Pro-Choice". 

Also, can I just say I love how your comment is about Orwell not just being "left wing" when the very notion of Left and Right are inherently Orwellian Newspeak concepts? The Left v Right is a false dichotomy perpetrated for the express purpose of limiting vocabulary and is a form of control over the discussion in the political landscape. Political ideologies are extremely complex, and have various aspects that fall all over the political spectrum. It's why you can't call Hitler Left or Right, because doing either would completely divest his ideology of its constituent parts.

replies.author: @Paul2377
replies.text: @TRENCHESandTREADS But it's not a human being. At the point I'm talking about it's a collection of cells. It has no feelings. I'm not suggesting late term abortions are OK, but early abortions are fine. People make mistakes. It's up to the woman carrying that collection of cells to decide what she wants to do with her *own body*. No one else's. I'm pretty sure you wouldn't like it if someone tried to tell you what to do, but weirdly you think it's fine to tell others what to do.

replies.author: @TRENCHESandTREADS
replies.text:
@Paul2377  Answer me this, if I crush a turtle egg, have I killed a turtle? Is there not a turtle life being ended by my action? Arguing that "it's a collection of cells" is EXTREMELY disingenuous because, guess what, we're all just a collection of cells. That collection of cells doesn't form into a duck, or a turtle, or whatever, it forms a human being. Once again I must point out that "collection of cells" is yet more Newspeak. It's an evil reframing of the argument to imply that something that is obviously so suddenly isn't. 

"It has no feelings" Right, but it will, because it is a human. This entire point is a justification for ending the life of invalids by the way, good to know you're pro murder on that front.

"People make mistakes" Right, and then they have to live with the consequences. If I got drunk and injured myself, and it would take 9 months for me to heal up and get back to work, that's on me. This is exactly the same thing. No one is owed sex, and women are choosing to have it knowing the risks. The ones that lose that dice roll are then murdering other humans to avoid suffering the consequences. 

"I'm pretty sure you wouldn't like it if someone tried to tell you what to do" I mean, you're right, I don't, but we have a little thing called LAWS, which is exactly that. If we didn't have said laws telling us what to do, I sure as hell know what would happen to a whole lot of current societies' problems, lol. I must reiterate, no one is telling women to have sex, they are choosing to do this, once again I catch you using Newspeak to frame the argument as us telling women what to do, when in reality they chose to be slatterns. More babies have been aborted in America than all combat deaths in WW1 and WW2 combined. Abortionists have more blood on their hands than literally Hitler.

One final note. You know those turtle eggs? It is a crime to destroy turtle eggs, eagle eggs, or *insert thousands of other species' eggs, because the government understood that you are ending the life of a member of said species. We literally give more rights to unborn turtles than we do humans, and that's evil.

replies.author: @Paul2377
replies.text:
@TRENCHESandTREADS When I say collection of cells, I mean an embryo has no thoughts or feelings. You're making it into an emotive argument calling it murder, as that brings to mind the killing of a person (and you criticise me for using language in a particular way!)

The turtle/eagle egg thing is different, as animals like that don't have a conscious decision to mate; nature drives it. Though if we're going to talk about birds, some of them abandon their nests or chicks for a variety of reasons. And that's often after the chicks hatch from their eggs... So I'm not sure bringing that into the argument helps your position.

It's also telling that you accuse a woman who wants an abortion of being a "slattern". Women in monogamous relationships with long term partners sometimes want abortions as it's not the right time in their life. And, let's not forget, some women want abortions after they've been raped (they can hardly be called slatterns in that scenario, as they didn't even ask for sex).

It's a bit of a moot point anyway, though, as I live in England where abortion has been legal for many years and there are no plans to change that for the reasons I've set out.

replies.author: @TRENCHESandTREADS
replies.text:
‚Äã@Paul2377  "When I say collection of cells, I mean an embryo has no thoughts or feelings." 

Already answered, I notice you completely ignored that lol. So I'll just repeat both my answers.
1. It WILL have feelings, that's not debatable. I know it's difficult for you to understand If>Then states of being, but come on, this is getting silly.
2. You are literally advocating for euthanasia of the extremely mentally challenged if you think "no thoughts or feelings" is a reasonable justification for ending a life.

"The turtle/eagle egg thing is different, as animals like that don't have a conscious decision to mate; nature drives it." 

Right, so you're agreeing with me that as humans women are capable of NOT mating and thus not getting pregnant, thanks for showing that you don't even understand your own position.

"Though if we're going to talk about birds, some of them abandon their nests or chicks for a variety of reasons. And that's often after the chicks hatch from their eggs... So I'm not sure bringing that into the argument helps your position."

I can't tell if this is you being deliberately obtuse or you're really just this way. The entire point about the turtle eggs was that they're ANIMALS and we put more legal value on their unborn young than we do on the unborn humans in this world. If you think mindless animals deserve more legal status than humans then you need to re-evaluate your priorities. Again, let me re-iterate, the governments in every Western nation are fully capable of looking at various animal's eggs and going 'this is obviously a member of that species, and we want to protect that species, therefore destroying the eggs is the same as killing a birthed one.' Yet for some reason we can't apply that standard to humans? Baffling.

"It's also telling that you accuse a woman who wants an abortion of being a "slattern". Women in monogamous relationships with long term partners sometimes want abortions as it's not the right time in their life." 

Again, if she didn't want to get pregnant, then she could have just not had sex lol, but instead she engaged in slattern behavior. Women aren't owed sex, even if they're in a monogamous relationship. Also, PER YOUR OWN ARGUMENT, women are not mindless animals, they are fully capable of not engaging in destructive mating habits and making conscious decisions.

"And, let's not forget, some women want abortions after they've been raped (they can hardly be called slatterns in that scenario, as they didn't even ask for sex)."

What a sick and disgusting statement. I can't imagine using rape pregnancies (less than 1% of all abortions by the way) to win an argument about abortion in general. I can't imagine what failure of a man one must be to hide behind the skirts of rape victims because they don't have the intellectual rigour to defend their stupid opinion. You don't make policy based on the extreme outliers, and it's telling that you Lefties always fall back on "Think of the rape victims!" whenever your arguments get even moderately challenged. Vile.

"It's a bit of a moot point anyway, though, as I live in England where abortion has been legal for many years and there are no plans to change that for the reasons I've set out." 

So because things are the way they are there's no reason to attempt to course correct back to when it wasn't messed up? No wonder you lot are getting conquered, you just lay down and die. 

Come back when you actually have valid arguments. I thought you Brits were supposed to be good at arguing, instead all I find is the pious waffling of an out of his depth Lefty.

author: @silkestein77
text:
Posie Parker/Kellie-Jay Keen is one amazing, courageous adult human female. I've written this song in her honour:
MY NOUN IS WOMAN
(Song for Kellie-Jay)




To those of you who like to curate speech,

I'm not subscribing to the lies you teach,

I won't surrender what belongs to me,

my nouns are truthful, and my thoughts are free.




It's adult human female, Miss

and Mrs., and it's ma'am.

I won't give up a single word

defining who I am:

My noun is woman.




It's not about how I identify,

I couldn't be a man if I would try,

it's not a feeling or ideology,

for I am one with my biology.




It's mother, daughter, girl, aunt, niece,

it's sister and it's wife,

I am not willing to ignore

the basic facts of life:

My noun is woman.




I stand with women everywhere,

yes, I am not alone.

No place or culture does exist

where it has not been known.

We are half of humanity; 

we claim it as our own:

Our noun is woman.
_
Copyright: Clara Abendstern
